sn55.41:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.
sn55.41:4.3: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.41:6.1: Furthermore, they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones …
sn55.41:6.4: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.
sn55.41:7.1: When a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that
sn55.41:7.2: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.
sn55.41:7.3: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.
sn55.41:8.1: It’s like trying to measure how much water is in the ocean. It’s not easy to say
sn55.41:8.2: how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.
sn55.41:8.3: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.
sn55.41:8.4: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that
sn55.41:8.5: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.
sn55.41:8.6: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.”
sn55.41:9.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn55.41:9.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn55.41:10.2: and though the rivers are many,
sn55.41:10.3: all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,
sn55.41:10.4: the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.
sn55.41:11.1: So too, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;
sn55.41:11.2: and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—
sn55.41:11.3: the streams of merit reach that astute person,
sn55.41:11.4: as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”
